description: From Middle English widren, wydderen (“to dry up, shrivel”), related to or perhaps an alteration of Middle English wederen (“to expose to weather”), from Old English wederian (“to expose to weather, exhibit a change of weather”).

verbs.description: wither (third-person singular simple present withers, present participle withering, simple past and past participle withered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To shrivel, droop or dry up, especially from lack of water.
(transitive) To cause to shrivel or dry up.
examples: There was a man which had his hand withered.

c. 1590–1592 (date written),  William Shakespeare,  “The Taming of the Shrew”, in  Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies […] (First Folio), London:  […]  Isaac Iaggard, and Ed[ward] Blount, published 1623, →OCLC, [Act IV, scene v]:This is man, old, wrinkled, faded, withered.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To lose vigour or power; to languish; to pass away.
examples: States thrive or wither as moons wax and wane.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become helpless due to emotion.
(transitive) To make helpless due to emotion.

description: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

entries.meaning: singular of withers (“part of the back of a four-legged animal that is between the shoulder blades”)

description: From Middle English wither, from Old English wiþer (“again, against”, adverb in compounds), from Proto-West Germanic *wiþr (“against, toward”).

adverbs.description: wither (comparative more wither, superlative most wither)

entries.meaning: (obsolete or chiefly in compounds) Against, in opposition to.

description: From Middle English witheren, from Old English wiþerian (“to resist, oppose, struggle against”).

verbs.description: wither (third-person singular simple present withers, present participle withering, simple past and past participle withered)
